metadata.title: Curvature changes and weight loss of polymeric nano-composite plates with consideration of the thermal cycle fatigue effects and different resin types_ An experimental approach

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Mechanics of Materials
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/mechmat
Curvature changes and weight loss of polymeric nano-composite plates with consideration of the thermal cycle fatigue effects and different resin types: An experimental approach Ali Tabatabaeian, Ahmad Reza Ghasemi⁎
Composite and Nanocomposite Research Laboratory, Department of Solid Mechanics, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, University of Kashan, Kashan, 87317-53153, Iran
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Polymer matrix composites (PMCs) Curvature Thermal fatigue Weight loss
A B S T R A C T
The cured shape of nano-composite laminates is one of the most important issues in structural engineering studies due to the direct effects of the curvature on the residual stresses. In this study, the curvature changes and weight loss of nano-composite plates with different epoxy resins are studied. Also, the effects of thermal fatigue, stacking sequence and thickness are investigated experimentally and residual stress relaxation over the time is reported. Experimental results showed that addition of multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) can cause different reactions on the various epoxy resins and the effects of addition of nanoparticles highly depend on the resin type and curing condition. It was also stablished that the curvature of lamina is closely dependent on thermal cycling numbers.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Polymer matrix composites (PMCs) are widely used in different structures due to their great mechanical and thermal properties (Bolimowski and Boczkowska, 2018; Moshrefzadeh-sani and Shokrieh, 2018; Singh et al., 2017). Different lay ups are designed for different applications (Nikforooz et al., 2018; Yazdani Sarvestani and Hojjati, 2017). It has been established that unsymmetrical laminates will have a curvature after curing while, symmetrical ones will be flat. The mentioned curvature highly depends on the thickness, curing temperature and the stacking sequence of the composite laminates. The importance of determination of curvature is due to its direct effects on the overall residual stresses. First studies on this subject were done by Hyer (Hyer, 1982, 1981). He investigated the room-temperature shapes of fourlayer unsymmetrical cross-ply laminates. He observed that the roomtemperature shapes of cross-ply laminates are strong function of their size and stacking arrangement. Depending on these parameters, the room-temperature shape of cross-ply unsymmetrical laminate can be a unique saddle shape or a cylindrical shape that can be snapped through to another cylindrical shape. Ren et al. (2003) studied the cured shape of cross-ply composite shells. They proposed a model based on Rayleigh-Ritz energy method to predict the cured shape of composite shells and compared it with experimental and analytical results. Available researches have been showed that the curvature of unsymmetrical
laminates can be controlled by addition of nanoparticles such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs) (Ghasemi et al., 2015; Shokrieh et al., 2014). Nan et al. (2016) studied the effects of addition of four different types of multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) on the electrical, mechanical and thermal properties of epoxy nano-composites. It was found that the dispersion of MWCNTs in solvents and epoxy was enhanced with the addition of surfactants. Lila et al. (2017) investigated the effects of fiber type on mechanical and thermal behavior of epoxy based composites. Three types of natural fibers were used as reinforcement. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) were used to study the fracture behavior of the developed composites. The results revealed that along with the applied pressure and viscosity of the matrix, surface roughness of the fiber also plays a significant role in deciding the mechanical properties and natural fiber with high surface roughness exhibits better mechanical properties. Despite of excellent properties of the CNTs, the application of CNTs in polymer composites has been limited owing to the: (1) difficulty of obtaining a homogenous dispersion of pristine CNTs in a polymer matrix. (2) lower interfacial adhesion between the pristine CNTs and the matrix compared to that of surface-treated CNTs. (3) adversity of application of high volume fractions (more than 5%) due to high viscosity (Soo-Jin et al., 2007). A lot of studies have been carried out about the influence of CNTs and their dispersion on epoxy resins (Arefi et al., 2018; Esbati and Irani, 2018; Naghashpour and Van Hoa, 2017; Romano et al., 2007; Wang et al., 2007). Cividanes et al.

⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: Ghasemi@Kashanu.ac.ir (A.R. Ghasemi).
Mechanics of Materials 131 (2019) 69–77
Available online 29 January 2019 0167-6636/ © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
T
(2007) presented a comprehensive review about the effects of CNTs on epoxy resin cure reaction using different techniques such as differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA) and luminescence spectroscopy. They encouraged other researchers to study the following issues: (1) Systematic study of the variables that may influence the homogeneity and the curing of the composites, (2) Study of variables that have not yet been explored, such as the purification and mixing method, (3) Study of the viscosity of the composite during the curing reaction. The study of the cure reaction of epoxy resin and carbon nanotube composites often shows controversial results. This is so due to the large number of variables that can influence the curing reaction, variables that have not been fully explored, and often are not mentioned in the works. For example, information such as type of CNT purification, type of impurities, diameter, length and aspect ratio of the nanotubes, the orientation of nano- tubes in the matrix, etc. Therefore, it is necessary to study systematically how the process variables can influence CNT homogeneity, and consequently, the curing reaction of composites.
Shah et al. (2018) investigated optimal cure cycle parameters for minimizing residual stresses in fiber-reinforced composite laminates. It was found that for specific cross-ply laminates with the span to thickness ratio of 125, an optimal cycle reduces the process induced curvature by 13% in comparison to the manufacturer's recommended cure cycle (MRCC) but increases the total cure time from 5 to 7.4 h LafarieFrenot et al. (2006) used a model of oxidation to determine the experimental conditions of an isothermal test ‘equivalent’ to a thermal cycling one, in terms of mas loss due to oxidation. After having checked this equivalence, a quantitative analysis of the damages induced by the two types of tests, was carried out. It was shown that the oxidation of a laminate in isothermal conditions results in damages, which concern only the skin of the sample. On the contrary, the coupling of such damage mechanisms with cyclic stresses in thermal cycling accelerates the damage processes and especially the matrix crack propagation from the surfaces to the core of the laminate.
Although several studies can be found about curing behavior of different epoxy matrix composites and the optimal curing conditions (Fereshteh-Saniee et al., 2018; Loleı¨ Khoun, 2010; Tifkitsis et al., 2018; Tsukada et al., 2017), a few researches have been done with particular consideration on the effects of various epoxy resins on the curvature of carbon nanotubes reinforced composites. Jin et al. (2015) performed a review research about the application of epoxy resins. They concluded that the properties of cured epoxy resins depend on the type of epoxy resin, curing agent, and curing process used. The toughness of epoxy resins can be improved by incorporating thermoplastic components, inorganics, carbon fibers, clay, and carbon nanotubes. It was also discussed that epoxy resins have a wide range of application including coatings, aerospace industry, electronic materials, and biomedical system. In a recent study by Wang et al. (2017), the impact behavior of composite laminates made of woven fabric and four different resin matrices was analyzed. They concluded that the impact behavior of fabric-reinforced laminates is significantly influenced by the matrix material. The laminates with flexible matrices had higher perforation resistance and energy absorption but larger extent of deformation and damage than the counterparts with more rigid matrices. Some other studies have been done about different resins and their properties and applications. Mungamurugu et al. (2017) stuided the long term performance of glass reinforced composites with different resins under marine environement. Teyssedre et al. (2006) investigated the curing and post curing luminescence in an epoxy resin. Moreovere, in a study by Yang et al. (2009), the preparation and analysis of a flexible curing agent for epoxy resin was reported. Ghasemi and Mohammadi-Fesharaki (Ghasemi and Mohammadi-Fesharaki, 2019) investigated the influence of different parameters such as thickness and curing temperature on cured shapes and residual stresses of un-symmetric composite laminate reinforced by multi wall carbon nanotubes.
A comprehensive literature review has been completed above. The
investigation of the cure reaction of epoxy resin and carbon nanotube composites often shows controversial results. This is so because of the large number of parameters that can affect the curing reaction. All mentioned researches have been emphasized that addition of nanoparticles results in reduction of the curvature of composite plates while, this phenomenon highly depends on the resin type and many other effective parameters including the curing and cooling temperatures, the method of CNT homogenizing, etc. The motivation of present study is to analyze the influences of some specific parameters such as: thickness, thermal fatigue, addition of carbon nanotubes and type of epoxy resin on the cured shape of unsymmetrical nano-composite laminates and residual stress relaxation over the time. Two different resins including ML 506 and KER 828 are considered and samples are fabricated with various weight fractions of MWCNTs. After that, samples are subjected to thermal fatigue condition. Then, the radius of curvature of each sample is carefully measured using a coordinate measuring machine (CMM). Finally, the influence of thermal fatigue and addition of MWCNTs into various resin types are studied and novel experimental observations on the curvature changes and weight loss of nano-composite plates are reported.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
In order to compare the influence of various epoxy resins, two different resins including the KER828 (supplied by Kumho P&B Chemicals Inc. (Korea)) and ML506 (supplied by Mokarrar Engineering Co. (Iran)) are used in fabrication of samples. Also, the unidirectional E-glass fibers are applied to reinforce the composite laminates. Some necessary thermo-mechanical properties of resins and fibers are presented in Tables 1 and 2, respectively.
Multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) are used as nanoparticles in this research (Table 2). It should be notice that all properties are evaluated at room temperature (25∘C).

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of specimens
sections.text:
In this investigation, hand lay-up method is applied to fabricate the unsymmetrical laminated composite and nano-composites. The first step of fabrication is to cut the fiber into plates with arbitrary dimensions. The specimens are divided into two different groups due to their epoxy resin. The first group is made with ML 506 with the size of 15 cm × 15 cm (resin and hardner mixed with ratio 115:15 by weight) and the second group is made with KER 828 epoxy resin with the size of 20 cm × 20 cm (resin and hardner mixed with ratio 100:10 by weight) (Fig. 1).
In order to analyze the influence of the MWCNTs on the cured-shape of specimens, each group has been prepared with and without MWCNTs. The stacking sequences of [02/902]T and [04/904]T are considered and specimens are fabricated. A schematic assortment of specimens is presented in Fig. 2. It should be noticed that for each state of samples, three specimens were made and the average value with standard deviation is reported in this paper. Fig. 3 shows the specimens before and after curing. As shown in this figure, the unsymmetrical layup arrangements (all of the specimens in this study) will have a curvature after curing.

sections.heading: 2.3. Thermal fatigue
sections.text: Several researchers have identified the cyclic thermal loading as one of the most critical loading schemes that could affect the life cycle of composite materials (Ghasemi et al., 2018; Mohamed and Taheri, 2018). In several engineering applications, composite materials often experience fluctuating temperatures. To the best of our knowledge, there is no standard or unified heating-cooling procedure to follow. Most works in this area have followed thermal cycle regimes that a given material would experience under a specific environmental condition of interest, in-service. A thermal cycling apparatus consisting of heating and cooling chambers and a rail system for specimen motion was assembled to provide the temperature cycle of the specimens (Ghasemi and Moradi, 2016). According to Iran climate in summer, the minimum and maximum temperature were considered 25∘C and 70∘C, respectively (Heidari-Rarani et al., 2014; Mohammad et al., 2016; Shokrieh et al., 2011). The specimens were subjected to 0, 50, 100, 150 and 200 thermal cycles with constant cooling and heating rates of 16∘C/ min and 4∘C/min, respectively. Fig. 4 shows an example of temperature record. Two curves show the temperature record of two sensors in which the red curve is related to the main sensor and shows the average temperature record in the space. While, the white one is related to the sensor which recorded the temperature of two sides of the specimens. It should be mentioned that the conditioning was done under constant humidity and it is assumed that the cooling or heating rate is not fast enough to induce thermal shock.

sections.heading: 2.4. Measurement of curvature
sections.text:
The curvature of each specimen was measured at three steps:
a) After fabrication b) After 5 months (before subjecting to thermal fatigue condition) c) After 5 months (after subjecting to thermal fatigue condition)
A coordinate measuring machine (CMM) was used to measure the curvature of samples (Fig. 5). The machine was set to consider 15 points along the length of samples and then plot a curve with these 15 points (Fig. 6). Finally, the radius of curvature was measured by the CMM software. It should be mentioned that for each sample, three radiuses of curvature were determined and the greatest one has been reported in this paper.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text: As shown in Fig. 2, samples are divided into two groups including: samples made by ML 506 epoxy resin and samples made by KER 828 epoxy resin. The first group focus on the influence of different weight fractions of MWCNTs on the ML 506 resin epoxy. While, the second group concentrate on the effects of MWCNTs on the KER 828 epoxy resin. Also, the role of thickness and residual stress relaxation over the time are investigated in second group. Finally, weight loss and thermal fatigue results of two groups are presented and discussed.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Influence of different weight fractions of MWCNTs on the ML 506 resin
sections.text:
The influence of different weight fractions of MWCNTs is presented in Fig. 7. As shown in this figure, addition of MWCNTs decreases the curvature of laminates. Comparison of various weight fractions of MWCNTs shows the 5.2%, 11.3% and 15.6% reduction of curvature due to addition of 0.1%, 0.25% and 0.5% of MWCNTs, respectively. The experimental results indicate that addition of MWCNTs to a composite sample (with 0% MWCNTs) causes more considerable effects on the curvature variations than addition of MWCNTs to a nano-composite
specimen (with 0.1% or more MWCNTs). It is also concluded that the cured shape of composite plates can be easily controlled by addition of appropriate amounts of nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Influence of thermal fatigue
sections.text:
The samples fabricated with ML 506 resin were subjected to 0, 50 and 100 cycles. It was observed that during the cooling phase of the thermal cycle, the curvature reaches to the maximum state. While, during the heating phase, the curvature declines dramatically and the nano-composite plates become almost flat. The reason of this phenomenon could be the temperature of heating chamber (70∘C) which is almost close to stress-free temperature of the composite samples. During the heating phase, the samples experience temperature close to stress-free temperature and their residual stresses are released. Then, they experience a temperature decrease during cooling phase and residual stresses are sprung up due to the difference between the coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) of fibers and resin epoxy and also different layers. Consequently, the curvature increases. It should be
mentioned that this pattern was observed for all samples. However, the amount of curvature changes was different for various specimens with different content of MWCNTs.
Fig. 8 shows the influence of thermal fatigue on the curvature of composite plates fabricated with ML 506 resin. As shown in this figure, the curvature increases as samples are subjected to thermal fatigue condition. There is a direct relationship between the number of thermal cycles and the curvature variation. Experimental results revealed that the most curvature changes are occurred during initial 50 cycles. It can be also concluded that the rate of curvature changes of nano-composite plates under thermal fatigue condition decreases with addition of appropriate amount of MWCNTs.

sections.heading: 3.1.3. Weight loss
sections.text:
The mass of all samples was precisely measured before and after of thermal fatigue condition using a scales with the sensitivity of 0.001 gr. Tables 3 shows the results of the weight loss of the samples fabricated with ML 506. As it was mentioned in previous researches
(Schoeppner et al., 2007), the mass of all samples decreases when they are subjected to thermal fatigue condition. It is observed that the number of thermal cycles is more noticeable parameter on the weight loss percentage of composites than the addition of nanoparticles. Considering Table 3, it is apparent that the weight loss of composite materials under thermal fatigue is reduced by addition of nanoparticles. The most weight loss percentage was observed in composite specimens (0% MWCNTs) which have experienced 150 thermal cycles.

sections.heading: 3.2. KER 828 epoxy resin
sections.text:
In this section, cured shape of composite plates which has been made by KER 828 epoxy is investigated. Two different states are considered to study the influence of thickness. Also, composites are
analyzed with and without addition of MWCNTs.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Influence of addition of MWCNTs on the KER 828 resin
sections.text: As shown in Figs. 9 and 10, addition of MWCNTs increases the curvature of composite plates in both [02/902]T and [04/904]T stacking sequences. It is observed that as the thickness becomes greater, the influence of addition of nanoparticles becomes more noticeable. It is clarified that addition of 1% MWCNTs leads to increase of the curvature up to 19%.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Influence of the thickness
sections.text:
Experimental results (Fig. 9) indicate that the curvature of composite plates can be well controlled by changing the thickness. By changing the stacking sequence of [02/902]T into [04/904]T, the curvature of composites (0% MWCNTs) and nanocomposites (1% MWCNTs) decrease 50.44% and 43.77%, respectively. As it is presented in Fig. 9, addition of 1% MWCNTs leads to only 19.57% increase of the curvature while, changing the thickness (8 layers into 4 layers) results in 50.44% increase of the curvature of composite plates. It should be noticed that however, the thickness and stacking sequence are effective parameters to control the curvature of composite laminates, it is sometimes not possible because of designing limitations. Therefore, investigation of various materials and their reactions to addition of nanoparticles could be so important to reach the optimal residual stress conditions. Accordingly, it is recommended for future studies to analytically
investigate the cure reaction and curvature changes of various epoxy resins due to addition of different types of nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Influence of thermal fatigue
sections.text: The samples with KER 828 resin were subjected to 0, 100 and 200 cycles. Similar to previous samples, the curvature of samples made by KER 828 resin increases when they are subjected to thermal cycling condition. The increase of curvature is almost linearly in composite plates without MWCNTs. While, the nano-composites (with 1% of MWCNTs) show different behavior under various number of thermal cycles. As shown in Fig. 11, the curvature variation is more noticeable during initial 100 cycles. It is revealed that curvature behavior of laminate is closely dependent on thermal cycling numbers.

sections.heading: 3.2.4. Curvature changes over the time
sections.text:
The curvature of nano-composite plates decreases over the time (Cowley and Beaumont, 1997). In this section, the curvature changes in composite and nano-composite plates after a period of 5 months will be studied. Experimental results indicate that the radius of curvature of all samples have been increased (the curvature has been decreased). The composite plates (0% MWCNTs) with stacking sequence of [02/902]T
and [04/904]T have had curvature decrease of 1.1% and 10.8%, respectively. It is clarified that the thickness plays an important role in curvature changes of composite plates over the time. The nano-composite plates (1% MWCNTs) with stacking sequence of [02/902]T and [04/904]T have experienced a curvature decrease of 23.7% and 7.2%, respectively. It is observed that the residual stress relaxation over the time, can be strongly affected by addition of nanoparticles. It is also revealed that the effect of addition of nano-particles is much more noticeable than the effects of the thickness. The most changes in curvature were observed in four-layer nano-composite plates (23.7%). Considering the obtained results in Table 4, it is indicated that the effects of thickness on the stress relaxation over the time is totally different in composite and nano-composite materials.

sections.heading: 3.2.5. Weight loss
sections.text:
The weight loss of composites and nano-composites made with KER 828 under thermal cycle fatigue is presented in this section. It is observed that the mass of samples decreases as they are subjected to cyclic temperature fluctuations. Comparison of the four-layer and eight-layer specimens demonstrates that the weight loss percentage under thermal fatigue becomes less noticeable in greater thicknesses. It is also revealed
that the weight loss percentage can be diminished by addition of MWCNTs. The most weight loss percentage in this group was observed in four-layer composite specimens (0% MWCNTs) which have been subjected to 200 thermal cycles (Table 5).

sections.heading: 3.3. Overall overview
sections.text: Experimental results reveal that the effects of addition of nanoparticles highly depend on the type of resin and curing condition (Luciana et al., 2007). For example, the KER 828 epoxy resin shows totally opposite results in curvature changes due to addition of nanoparticles in comparison to the ML 506 epoxy resin. One can conclude that each group of epoxy resins, have their special properties and curing reactions which should be tested to be reliable to use in scientific researches. Additionally, the amount of added MWCNTs is noticeably results in the cure reaction and consequently the curvature of the laminates (Yang et al., 2008). Comparison of the weight loss percentage of different specimens indicate that no matter what the resin type is, the mass of composite materials declines with the increment of the number of thermal cycles. This is due to the matrix degradation and evaporation of the moisture of the resin Also, it can be concluded that addition of nanoparticles leads to decrease of the weight loss percentage of the nano-composites under thermal cycle fatigue condition.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this research, the motivation was investigation of the influence of various parameters on the curvature and weigh loss percentage of composite and nano-composite structures. The cured shape of nanocomposite laminates is one of the most important issues in structural engineering studies due to the direct effects of the curvature on the overall thermal residual stresses. Composite and nanocomposite plates were fabricated using two various resins. Samples were divided to two groups: the first group were made by ML 506 epoxy resin with stacking sequence of [02/902]T while, the second group were made by KER 828 epoxy resin with stacking sequences of [02/902]T and [04/904]T. Four different weight fractions of MWCNTs were applied (0%, 0.1%, 0.25%, 0.5%) in first group to analyze the influence of various weight fractions of nanoparticles on the ML 506 resin. While, the concentration of second group was on the effects of thickness and also addition of MWCNTs (1%) on the KER 828 resin. It was observed that addition of MWCNTs can cause different reactions on the various epoxy resins. Experimental results revealed that the effects of addition of nanoparticles highly depend on the type of resin and curing condition. The curvature of samples which had been made by ML 506 were reduced as the nanoparticles were added into composite laminates while, the curvature of samples which had been made by KER 828 were increased with addition of MWCNTs. The experimental results demonstrated that addition of MWCNTs to a composite sample (with 0% MWCNTs) causes more considerable effects on the curvature variations than addition of MWCNTs to a nano-composite specimen (with 0.1% or more MWCNTs). The results indicated that thickness is an important parameter to control the curvature of composite plates. However, it cannot be the best option to work with because of designing limitations. Therefore, investigation of various materials and their reactions to addition of nanoparticles could be so important to reach the optimal curvature behavior. Accordingly, it is recommended for future studies to analytically investigate the cure reaction and curvature changes of various epoxy resins due to addition of different types of nanoparticles.
It was observed that the residual stress relaxation over the time, can
be strongly affected by addition of nanoparticles and the effect of addition of nano-particles is much more noticeable than the effects of the thickness. The most changes in curvature were observed in four-layer nano-composite plates (23.7%).
Investigation of samples under different number of thermal cycles showed that curvature of lamina is closely dependent on thermal cycling numbers. The most curvature changes were occurred during initial 50 cycles. It can be also concluded that the rate of curvature changes of nano-composite plates under thermal fatigue condition decreases with addition of appropriate amount of MWCNTs.
Experimental results revealed that no matter what the resin type is, the mass of composite materials declines with the increment of the number of thermal cycles. It can be concluded that addition of nanoparticles leads to decrease of the weight loss percentage of nano-composites under thermal fatigue condition. It was observed that the number of thermal cycles is more noticeable parameter on the weight loss percentage of composites than the addition of nanoparticles.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: The authors are grateful to the Iran National Science Foundation (INSF) for supporting this research with Grant No. 96001615.

referenceMentions.context: Polymer matrix composites (PMCs) are widely used in different structures due to their great mechanical and thermal properties (Bolimowski and Boczkowska, 2018; Moshrefzadeh-sani and Shokrieh, 2018; Singh et al., 2017).

Available researches have been showed that the curvature of unsymmetrical laminates can be controlled by addition of nanoparticles such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs) (Ghasemi et al., 2015; Shokrieh et al., 2014).
(3) adversity of application of high volume fractions (more than 5%) due to high viscosity (Soo-Jin et al., 2007).

A lot of studies have been carried out about the influence of CNTs and their dispersion on epoxy resins (Arefi et al., 2018; Esbati and Irani, 2018; Naghashpour and Van Hoa, 2017; Romano et al., 2007; Wang et al., 2007).

A lot of studies have been carried out about the influence of CNTs and their dispersion on epoxy resins (Arefi et al., 2018; Esbati and Irani, 2018; Naghashpour and Van Hoa, 2017; Romano et al., 2007; Wang et al., 2007).

Although several studies can be found about curing behavior of different epoxy matrix composites and the optimal curing conditions (Fereshteh-Saniee et al., 2018; Loleı ̈ Khoun, 2010; Tifkitsis et al., 2018; Tsukada et al., 2017), a few researches have been done with particular consideration on the effects of various epoxy resins on the curvature of carbon nanotubes reinforced composites.

Ghasemi and Mohammadi-Fesharaki (Ghasemi and Mohammadi-Fesharaki, 2019) investigated the influence of different parameters such as thickness and curing temperature on cured shapes and residual stresses of un-symmetric composite laminate reinforced by multi wall carbon nanotubes.

Several researchers have identified the cyclic thermal loading as one of the most critical loading schemes that could affect the life cycle of composite materials (Ghasemi et al., 2018; Mohamed and Taheri, 2018).

metadata.abstractText: The cured shape of nano-composite laminates is one of the most important issues in structural engineering studies due to the direct effects of the curvature on the residual stresses. In this study, the curvature changes and weight loss of nano-composite plates with different epoxy resins are studied. Also, the effects of thermal fatigue, stacking sequence and thickness are investigated experimentally and residual stress relaxation over the time is reported. Experimental results showed that addition of multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) can cause different reactions on the various epoxy resins and the effects of addition of nanoparticles highly depend on the resin type and curing condition. It was also stablished that the curvature of lamina is closely dependent on thermal cycling numbers.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
